ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This is a great course to develop your understanding of the state of the world's financial order and disorder, of its progress and backwardness.

An extremely novel and interdisciplinary look at the problems of tax havens, illicit financial flows and the problem of financial sleaze around the world. A great introduction to an important and new field with great access to experts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The setup of the course whereby each week consisted of different readings, topics and guest speakers was conducive to a comprehensive understanding of the course's theme.

The class wasn't very structured, it was moreso just a group of new people coming in each week to talk about topics relating to global tax justice. Surprisingly, though, it ended up being sort of the same material taught about week after week. I wish this class had a better organization and moved through more material. The guest speakers were all amazing in their own right, but some classes were definitely more fruitful than others. We received zero feedback about our intermediate assignments (2 class preparations/essays) prior to handing in our final paper, and received 0 feedback overall (as of yet nothing turned in has been returned). The first piece of info that I'll be getting on how I did in this class will be my final grade.

Very knowledgeable seminar leaders and guest lecturers who were effective in synthesizing both technical accounting/economic aspects and the broader justice issues in different cases of illicit financial flows around the world. At times the class felt a bit unstructured and it would be great if in future iterations there were more focus on ensuring all participants understand some of the technical nuances better.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I strongly recommend this course to any student, regardless of major. It provides insight into the world's financial state and the professors and guest lecturers are amazing, and are leading experts in their fields.

Interesting material and worth learning about, but this class could have been way more. I'd say take it to hear the guest speakers, but I'm not sure that's enough to justify a slot in one's class schedule.
Absolutely recommend! This is the start of an important field and it's happening at Yale...take advantage of it.
